description:
Pseudomyrmex gracilis is a species of ant belonging to the genus Pseudomyrmex, also known as the graceful twig ant or slender twig ant. This arboreal ant species is native to the tropical and subtropical regions of the Americas, ranging from Mexico to Argentina.

Pseudomyrmex gracilis is a slender and elongated ant, with a characteristic long and cylindrical body shape. Workers typically measure around 6-8 millimeters in length. The species is characterized by its long and narrow head, large eyes, and long legs and antennae, which are adaptations for its arboreal lifestyle.

These ants are known to inhabit the branches and trunks of trees, where they build their nests in the hollow stems or twigs. They are predominantly carnivorous, feeding on a variety of insects and other small arthropods. Pseudomyrmex gracilis plays an important role in the ecosystem by contributing to the regulation of insect populations in their native habitats.

The species exhibits a range of defensive behaviors, including the ability to sting and release irritating chemicals when threatened. Pseudomyrmex gracilis is considered a relatively common and widespread species within its geographical distribution, and it is not currently listed as a threatened or endangered species.
